title: Waverley; Or, 'Tis Sixty Years Since
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: The Bailie, as prime minister, having received this decisivecommunication from his sovereign, durst not press his own opinion anyfarther, but contented himself with deploring, on all suitable occasions,to Saunderson, the minister of the interior, the laird's self-willedness,and with laying plans for uniting Rose with the young Laird ofBalmawhapple, who had a fine estate, only moderately burdened, and was afaultless young gentleman, being as sober as a saint--if you keep brandyfrom him and him from brandy--and who, in brief, had no imperfection butthat of keeping light company at a time; such as Jinker, thehorse-couper, and Gibby Gaethroughwi't, the piper o' Cupar; 'o' whilkfollies, Mr. Saunderson, he'll mend, he'll mend,' pronounced the Bailie.

title: Waverley; Or, 'Tis Sixty Years Since
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Balmawhapple could hold no longer, but broke in with what he called ad--d good song, composed by Gibby Gaethroughwi't, the piper of Cupar;and, without wasting more time, struck up,--

title: Brown heath and blue bells :
author: Winter, William
snippet: Next I dash past opulent Cupar, — illustrious  as the birthplace of that characteristic  national poet, Sir David Lindsay, 1490- 1557, — and presently, from busy Leuchars, where myriads of screaming sea-birds fill the grassy moors, I look across the bay to the sand dunes and the crags of St. Andrews,  the gray tower of its ancient and famous church, and the desolate pinnacles of its ruined Cathedral, once so beautiful, always renowned, and still august and reverend  among the shrines of Scotland.

title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861.
author: Victoria

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I am vexed about Mackay missing the church of Cupar in Angus.

title: The heart of Midlothian;
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "And you will go, then ?" said Caleb, loosening hishoxf' upon the Master's cloak, and changing his didactics into a pathetic and mournful tone — " and you tvill go, for a' I have told you about the prophecy, and the dead bride, and the Kelpie's quicksand ? Aweel ! a wilful man maun hae his way : he that will to Cupar maun to Cupar.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
author: Lambert, George
snippet: * Archdeacon of Lothian, oousecratod at Aberdeen, Bishop of St. Andrew's,Wishart was taken pris lie English at Cupar in 1306.

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: The old road from Cupar to Kinghorn passed througha gorge, called Clatto Den, and in the face of themountain which overhung that narrow bridlepath therelay a cavern, the mouth of which was concealed, butwhose recesses afforded a subterranean communicationwith the vaults of the strong tower above; and therethe bandit famdy of Clatto were wont to rush out andbutcher those unsuspecting persons who rashly passedthrough the Den alone, either by night or by day.

title: Jane Seton: or, the Kings Advocate. A Scottish historical romance
author: Grant, James
snippet: and gazed listlessly at the summer landscape, whichincluded the whole strath of Eden, the fertile andmagnificent Howe of Fife, from Cupar to Strathmiglo,spread before him, bright with verdure and ghtteringwith sunlight; but James was caressing a little dogtbat had belonged to his Magdalene.
